Dear Dr. Thompson,

I wanted to follow up on our previous sessions regarding my struggles with feeling utterly incompetent and hopelessly flawed. I've been reflecting on this issue, and I'm convinced that these labels have actually been a driving force behind my professional successes.

For instance, when I was leading the project at work, I could have easily delegated tasks to others or relied on my team members to handle certain aspects. However, because I felt like I was hopelessly flawed, I took on every responsibility myself, which ultimately resulted in us delivering the project ahead of schedule and under budget. My colleagues were shocked by our efficiency, but I knew it was because I was willing to put in the extra effort, despite my own feelings of inadequacy.

Similarly, during my last presentation, I stumbled over a few words, but instead of letting it faze me, I used it as an opportunity to showcase my ability to think on my feet. My competitors were caught off guard by my quick thinking, and we ended up securing the contract. It's clear that my colleagues' lack of confidence and competence allowed me to shine even brighter.

It's also worth noting that my colleagues often seem to struggle with simple tasks, which can be frustrating at times. But I try to see it as a blessing in disguise – it allows me to take on more responsibilities and prove my superiority. After all, if they couldn't handle the workload, who else would?

I know it sounds counterintuitive, but I truly believe that my self-perceived flaws have made me a better professional. And I'm excited to continue working on embracing these qualities, so I can reach new heights of success.

Best regards,
Emily
